Posts.Content: May 17, 2009 09:59PM Jeanne_D wrote: I would most certainly get a second opinion.  I have never heard of having a postive node and NOT doing chemo.  I would think that is like playing with fire.  If the cancer is in your nodes, that means it can travel anywhere in your body.  Get a 2nd opinion!

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2009 03:21AM Jeanne_D wrote: Jennywren, first, the SUN itself is linked to skin cancer, so, does that mean that noone ever goes out in the SUN?  NO!  Do tanning beds actually and factually cause skin cancer?  NOONE KNOWS..it is NOT proven.  I am NOT playing with my life.  If I choose to go tanning next year, I will, as this is my life.  And, if you choose not to, fine, that is your life, your choice.  I am very sorry about your SIL, whatever that is, and hope that they will be ok.  And, I never said a tanning bed is safer than the sun.  And, as far as being uneducated and naive, look in the mirror, because somewhere, someone should have taught you some manners, as it appears you have none.  I dare to say it is not polite to attack a bc survivor or call them names, just because their opinion differs from yours.  Grow up and learn some manners.  I pray it is not too late!

Posts.Content: May 29, 2009 11:24PM Jeanne_D wrote: I did the full radiation treatments and boosters and am glad that I did.  I would rather have had a few inconvenient side effects that go away quickly than to have a shortened version and miss those stray cancer cells.  Why even bother at all I guess would be my question.
Posts.Title: 3 weeks of radiation seaotter lauribob

Posts.Content: Jeanne_D wrote: I was told NEVER to expose the radiated breast to the sun.  However, I had breast cancer before and had radiation and I tanned in the REAL sun and tanning booth for years.  It was probably 4 or 5 months later, but, I did.  But, that was 23 years ago.  So, how soon has anyone tanned in the real sun or a tanning booth after they finished radiation treatments?  My radiation oncologist told me if I do now or too soon..I would wind up with a 3rd degree burn, which I do not want.  But, dang it..summer is comingggggggggggggggggggg Dx 1/8/2009, IDC, <1cm, Stage IB, Grade 1, 0/0 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Sun on Radiated Area..How Soon??? Jeanne_D scarp

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 10:48PM Jeanne_D wrote: Like you said, this is new and they are just now doing studies.  Who knows what they will find.  But, I would rather take the "normal" amount of rads and be sure then take a shortened treatment of rads and think I am safe.  I would always be wondering..should I have taken more rads since nothing has been proven that the 3 weeks works?  Sounds like a dangerous risk of your life and your body to me.  But, good luck to you.
Posts.Title: 3 weeks of radiation seaotter lauribob

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 10:50PM - edited May 31, 2009 10:50PM by Jeanne_D Knowledgeforpower, I assume the reason you are only having 15 rads is because you are having chemo, which is normal.  Almost every chemo bc patient has a shortened rad treatment plan, that I know.  Cause with Stage 3 and postive nodes, chemo is always recommended.  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: 3 weeks of radiation seaotter lauribob

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2009 01:26AM - edited Jun 2, 2009 01:26AM by Jeanne_D I just wish any or all of you the best of luck if you take, have taken or are going to take the shortened version of rads.  I have never heard of it in the United States yet being proven as an effective treatment.  I have just read that they were doing trials of it.  I would prefer not to be a guinea pig with my life.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: 3 weeks of radiation seaotter lauribob

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2009 03:15PM - edited Jun 3, 2009 03:20PM by Jeanne_D Just want to wish you good luck tabbygirl if you do the 3 weeks.  And yes, ask lots of questions and ask to see long term results with it.  That is important!  I read the article that you posted and it all indicates that the 3 week rad is still in the trial stage.  So, there are no long term studies or patients to show whether it works or not.  Or, is there something else there that I didn't see?  Good luck hon!
Posts.Title: 3 weeks of radiation seaotter lauribob

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2009 12:13PM - edited Jun 1, 2009 12:14PM by Jeanne_D Use ONLY what your radiation oncologist tells you to use.  I used Biafine during the day for the lil burn that I got toward the end of the 37 treatments, and, used Aquaphor at night, because it was so greasy and stains everything you wear with it.  It seems radiation oncologist's vary inre to what you can use.  So, ask your doctor.  And, I started using Aquaphor right from the start to keep my skin moist, and, it helped.  So, start right away, would be my recommendation on the cremes.  And, don't put anything on your skin 4 hours prior to your rad treatment!   Good luck!
Posts.Title: Creams/lotions for rads Leah_S desdemona222b

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2009 11:14PM Jeanne_D wrote: Your radiated breast has scar tissue in it and that is why it is bigger than your non radiated breast.  It will go down when you start healing more.  Usually, about 6 months to a year.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Breast bigger after radiation rgiuff kimaesha

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2009 01:04AM Jeanne_D wrote: I am having my "boosters" now.  I have 8 more to go.  I am to have a total of 37..25 to the whole area and 12 "boosters" to the tumor site.  I only burnt in one place..near my collarbone.  I got a little pink, but, nothing bad.  My main problem has been the radiation dermatitis.  It is like little red bumps that itch, and, itch bad.  That, to me, is the worse part.
Posts.Title: Just started Radiation cook1 Neblin

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2009 02:41PM Jeanne_D wrote: My radiation oncologist prohibited tamoxifen while I was taking radiation, and, so did my oncologist.  Although I can't exactly explain it like they did, I will try.  The tamoxifen more or less chases around looking for the estrogen positive cells to conquer, kind of like pacman.   Well, when you are taking rads, you don't want ANY cells moving around.  You want them to stay put.  That is the purpose of radiation, to kill any stray cancer cells left.  Obviously, other oncologists and radiation oncologists differ, but, what mine said made a lot of sense and I didn't want to take any chances.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Taking tomaxifen while going through radiation bqswnnhn09 1Cathi

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2009 04:45PM - edited Jul 7, 2009 04:50PM by Jeanne_D The shortened version of rads is still in the clinical trial stage.  It has no long term proven results.  That is why insurance companies won't pay for it.  It is called experimental treatment.  And, I am glad that I had the 37 rad treatments.  And, I am glad that they zapped my lymph nodes and all of my breast tissue.  It killed any stray cancer cells that may be still there.  After all, they don't just stay at the tumor site, they move around.  I wish you the best of luck in your future!
Posts.Title: Twice a day rads? cancerkicker bwbly

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2009 11:00PM - edited Jul 9, 2009 11:06PM by Jeanne_D I am glad it worked out for you Jenbal so far. I am surprised that your radiation oncologist would do the short rads with you as I see you are stage 3, which is aggressive cancer.  I just think that people need to be informed that it is a clinical trial and that there is no long term proof that it works.  And, it only targets the tumor site and you have breast tissue clear up to your collar bone, clear under your breast and your lymph nodes should be zapped too.  That is another reason it makes no sense to me.  They are missing so many hot spots.  What insurance do you have?  I don't know of any that covers it.  Most consider it clinical trial/ experimental and won't cover it.  Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: Twice a day rads? cancerkicker bwbly

Posts.Content: May 28, 2009 12:02AM Jeanne_D wrote: I didn't tire for several weeks with rads.  And, if I did, I would try and take a nap during the day.  I had 37 treatments and have been done now about 3 weeks and NOW I am exhausted.  I wish you the best of luck.
Posts.Title: Fatigue at the beginning of radiation? Linda37 Mary22

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2009 11:57PM - edited Apr 28, 2009 11:58PM by Jeanne_D I am almost done with rads.  I will have a total of 37...25 to the entire side almost and 12 boosters to the tumor site.  I really never burnt..I got a lil pink in about 3 areas.  I had radiation clear up into almost my neck  because there are lymph nodes there and then down to right under my breast.  The area around my collar bone is what got the pinkest.  But now..I have those stupid red itchy bumps on my breast.  I didn't have them on my breast until they started the boosters.  grrrrrrrrrrrr  I hate them!

Posts.Title: ITCHING!!!! Suggestions? Eldub Estepp

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2009 10:42AM Jeanne_D wrote: I use the hydrocortisine creme, biafine, aquafor and aloe vera gel too.  It all helps for a little while, but yes, the itching comes back bad.  I have itched and when i do....the little red bumps bleed and hurt worse..so do NOT itch!  You are almost done!  It will go away probably very quickly when you finish.  I still have 13 to go   My radiation oncologist said there was nothing else to use that he would recommend or approve.  Good luck to you!  p.s. someone on here wrote about JeansCreme...you might check out the website.  i think it is just   jeanscream.com

Posts.Title: Itching and Red Bumps during Radiation Jeanne_D Nyr4evr

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2009 02:04PM - edited Apr 14, 2009 08:40AM by Jeanne_D I am at #20 in my radiation treatments.  I have 5 more to go of the "regular" ones, then 12 boosters.  My radiation oncologist and pretty much everything I have read says..If you have to go in the sun..wear the strongest sun block there is and make sure the area is covered with clothes.  My oncologist told me if you don't...you will get the worst 3rd degree burn imaginable.  I was told to stay out of the sun for 1 year after treatment.  I don't want a disfiguring burn.  Good luck to you hon!
